text:
Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?





I developed a Price-to-Safety index to compare the safety and affordability of suburbs in Melbourne when it comes to rental.















Auditing elderly accessibility of MTR stations in Hong Kong





Which MTR stations needs improvement to better accomodate the ageing population in Hong Kong? I developed an assessment framework to evaluate how well MTR stations serve elderly population.

title: Linh Ngo
text:
I build data systems and business processes that connect business strategy with execution — from designing analytics pipelines, data models, and dashboards that drive measurable impact, to building and optimizing team operations.


Professionally, my work sits at the intersection of data analytics, analytics engineering, and business strategy.
I’ve built and scaled analytics in fintech, SaaS, and consulting - from optimizing data pipelines and implementing self-service analytics at a U.S. tech startup, to leading growth and customer operations at a Vietnamese fintech, and supporting a business transformation for a major bank client.
Personally, I’m a long-distance runner, a frequent cafe-goer, a solo traveler, and a journaler. Fun fact: I have solo-travelled around SEA, I finish 13 journals every year on average.
Find out more about my work through my blogs and github repo.




Relearning and diving deeper into data engineering and pipeline design - exploring how modern data stacks can bridge the gap between technical systems and business impact
Developing new visualization methods to support high-dimensional compositional data through my new R package prefviz
Pursuing my project R1000, where I try to get rejected 1000 times in 2026 to get more comfortable with rejections and more importantly, take myself closer to my career and life goals. (Last updated: 53 rejections by 2026-02-21)





Languages: SQL, Python, R
Tools: dbt, Airbyte, Fivetran, Airflow, Git, Power BI, Tableau, Google Data Studio
Cloud: Snowflake, Azure Data Factory
Skills: ELT & data modelling, CI/CD for pipelines, data quality monitoring, and metric standardization

title: Quantifying Healthcare-associated Infection in Germany: Research Reveals Heavy Burden from Preventable Harm
text:
Hospitals are designed to heal, yet many patients leave them sicker than when they arrived — not because of their original illness, but because of healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). These infections arise during hospital care and are a major cause of avoidable deaths, disability, and healthcare costs across Europe. Germany is known for its advanced medical infrastructure and high hygiene standards. Yet, data from Zacher et al. (2019) suggest that its infection burden may be higher than the European average.
I’m exploring how severe HAIs-related health burden actually is, and what factors might explain the paradox of high infection rates in a strong healthcare system through a deep-dive into the paper “Application of a new methodology and R package reveals a high burden of healthcare-associated infections (HAI) in Germany compared to the average in the European Union/European Economic Area, 2011 to 2012” by Zacher et al. (2019).

title: Quantifying Healthcare-associated Infection in Germany: Research Reveals Heavy Burden from Preventable Harm
text:
What is healthcare-associated infection (HAI)?
HAI is a term used to describe infectious diseases that are associated with hospitalizations. These infections can arise from a variety of sources, including infections from patients, staff, and equipment.
This study focuses on five most common HAIs, namely:

Healthcare-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI)
Healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP)
Healthcare-associated primary bloodstream infection (BSI)
Healthcare-associated urinary tract infection (UTI)
Surgical site infection (SSI)

title: Quantifying Healthcare-associated Infection in Germany: Research Reveals Heavy Burden from Preventable Harm
section: How is HAIs-related health burden measured?
text:
How is HAIs-related health burden measured?
The author measures HAIs-related health burden through 3 key metrics:

The number of HAIs incidence
The number of deaths attributed to each HAI
The number of disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) due to HAIs: DALYs is a measure of years of lost healthy life, combining years of life lost (YLLs) with years lived with disability (YLDs). This metric enables a common ground to rank and compare the health burden of different HAIs.

Data used in this analysis is collected from European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) Point Prevalence Survey (2011–2012).
Analysis method is a built-upon from the Burden of Communicable Diseases in Europe (BCoDE) framework, yet enabling a more reliable estimation of HAIs-related health burden in cases of smaller sample size and varying survey protocols. You can find out more about their methodology through the accompanying R packages BHAI.

title: Quantifying Healthcare-associated Infection in Germany: Research Reveals Heavy Burden from Preventable Harm
text:
What does the data reveal?
A substantial and concerning burden of HAIs is found in Germany, especially when benchmarked against other European countries, and other communicable diseases.

Overall HAIs-related health burden



Table 1: Annual burden of five types of HAIs in Germany






The study estimated 478,222 cases of the five selected HAIs in Germany, leading to 16,245 attributable deaths and 248,920 DALYs (Table 1).
To put these number into perspective, the author benchmarked the burden of HAIs against other common communicable diseases like influenza, Salmonella, hepatitis B, and measles. The comparison is staggering: The burden of all five HAIs combined (308.2 DALYs per 100,000 population) is almost eight times higher than the combined burden of four common communicable diseases (39.4 DALYs per 100,000 population).



Table 2: Comparison the EU/EEA average further emphasizes a heavier national burden despite strong hygiene standards.






Furthermore, the burden of HAIs in Germany is overall higher than the EU/EEA average, with HAIs incidence being 27% higher, attributable death being 29% higher and DALYs being 6% higher (Table 2).


Disproportionate impact of HAIs
The sheer volume of HAIs is just one part of the story, but the analysis also revealed a crucial insights into where the true severity lies - fatality rate.






Figure 1: Contribution to overall burden is not evenly distributed across five HAIs due to differences in fatality rate, with HAP and BSI being much more deadly despite lower case number.



As shown in Figure 1 and Table 2, Healthcare-associated Pneumonia (HAP) and Primary Bloodstream Infection (BSI) were responsible for a whopping 51% of all DALYs, even though they represented only 28% of the total cases. In contrast, UTI registered 45% of all cases, yet only 27% of DALYs. These number show the deadly impact of HAP and BSI, calling for aggressive prevention measures for these diseases.


Reasons lie in the capacity challenge
Given the high hygiene standard imposed across German healthcare system, the existing substantial burden of HAIs is rather surprising. A deeper look into the system suggests the potential root cause being the country’s large hospital capacity and high hospitalization rate. Even with generally good hygiene standards, a higher volume of patients being admitted means more individuals are exposed to the risk of acquiring an HAI. When you increase the population at risk, the overall incidence per general population rises, inflating the total burden metrics.

title: Quantifying Healthcare-associated Infection in Germany: Research Reveals Heavy Burden from Preventable Harm
section: Conclusion: What we learnt and The way forward
text:
Conclusion: What we learnt and The way forward
The central question - how severe is HAIs-related health burden actually in Germany? - is answered by three key findings:

The absolute burden of HAIs in Germany is substantial (≈ 250,000 DALYs annually), yet impacts differ across types of HAIs due to varying fatality rate.
Relative to other diseases, HAIs account for almost eight times more healthy life lost.
Relative to other European nations, HAIs-related health burder in Germany is modestly but consistently 6% higher.
One potential driven for such heavy burden is from high volume of hospital admission, inflating the number of incidents and total burden metrics.

Such findings imply the critical role of reducing unnecessary hospitalization and continued adherence to hygiene and infection prevention measures on alleviating HAIs burden in Germany.

title: End-to-end implementation of Mixpanel for self-service product analytics
text:
This is how I helped Otrafy’s CEO, who is my career role model to this day, provide complete visibility into user behavior and retention, and empower non-technical users to self-serve their analytics needs with a product analytics tool - Mixpanel.
Otrafy is a B2B SaaS company that provides a document management platform for food manufacturers to collaborate with their suppliers, ensure their food safety and compliance with FDA regulations. The company was undergoing a major strategic shift from door-to-door sales and onboarding to a freemium, self-service model. Leadership anticipated a surge in user sign-ups and activation volumns, and would like to understand more about the user journey upon sign-up, and identify any bottlenecks in the onboarding process. In order to do so, the company needs to implement a product analytics tool that can track user behavior and provide insights into user engagement and retention.

title: End-to-end implementation of Mixpanel for self-service product analytics
text:
Provider selections
The market for product analytics tools is crowded, with a wide range of options available. Along with Mixpanel, I evaluated severals, including Amplitude, Heap, Segment, Google Analytics, etc.
Below are the criteria I used to evaluate and compare different providers:

Pricing - Does the pricing fit the company’s annual budget and anticipated growth?
Ease of implementation - How much time and how many engineers would be required to implement the solution?
Availability of SDKs, community support and customer services - How easy is it to get help?
Integration with existing stack - Is reverse ETL possible to sync data back to the data warehouse? Can it integrate with other tools in the stack, such as CRM, marketing automation, etc.?
Analytics functionality - What are the ranges of metrics and visualizations that the tool can provide?
Learning curve for non-technical users - How easy is it to get started with the tool?

In the end, Mixpanel won for its ease of implementation, availability of supports and documentation, and comprehensive analytics functionality. The pricing was also reasonable for the company’s needs and budget.

title: End-to-end implementation of Mixpanel for self-service product analytics
text:
Requirement mapping
Products and Customer Success team were the main users for the solution. Upon discussion, the team and I agreed to cover the entire platform feature set, and all buttons and options in the UI in a phased approach.
The first phase would cover the early stages of user journey (sign-up, onboarding, activation, etc.) and core features (create documents, send requests, etc.). The second phase would cover additional features such as customer support, feedback, and analytics.
The solution is expected to cover the entire user journey, from sign-up, onboarding to activation and beyond.

title: End-to-end implementation of Mixpanel for self-service product analytics
text:
Co-development with Engineering team
In collaboration with the Engineering team, I worked on the following three areas:

Supervise the implementation of tracking user events and properties using Mixpanel’s APIs, and provide requirement clarification when needed.
Designed pipeline to reverse ETL data to Mixpanel, and integrate data from Mixpanel with other tools like CRM, marketing automation, etc.
Develop a one-stop product analytics dashboard in Mixpanel for key metrics




Source: Mixpanel’s Documentation

title: End-to-end implementation of Mixpanel for self-service product analytics
text:
User education
I held a number of training sessions with the Product, Customer Success and Leadership team to onboard them to the new tools. The training sessions were hands-on, and accompanied by mini-homeworks and documentations to ensure understanding.

title: Putting ternary plots on higher-dimensional spaces
text:
I recently explored the world of computational statistics, or put it simply,building softwares that implement statistical theories. For me, it was building new visualization methods that can help me better understand the data I’m working with.
prefviz is a new R package for interactive and high-dimensional ternary plot that I developed, along with my supervisors Di and Damjan. Hopefully I can publish it on CRAN (aka production version of R packages) by end of March 2026!
Find out more about the package and its features via:

prefviz website
prefviz presentation

title: Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?
text:
Personal notes: If you’re like me and have a pattern of uprooting your life every 2-3 years to move to a new city (or even continent!), you will 100% relate to the pain of finding a decent rental place to call home. As a young female who mostly moves solo, there is always this burning question of “Which part of the city should I stay given my limited budget and the seemingly skyrocketing chaos and crime rate across the globe?”. That is the motivation behind this project, and this is what I was desperately looking for from at least one real estate listing page.
Source code is available here

title: Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?
text:
Data collection




Table 1: Data sources and respective objectives











Data
Source
Objective




2021 Census GeoPackages - G01
ABS
To collect Population of all suburbs in Melbourne. This is used to calculate incident rate per 100 residents


2021 Census GeoPackages - G02
ABS
To collect Median weekly rent and Geospatial boundaries of all suburbs in Melbourne


Recorded Criminal Incidents
CSA
To collect all criminal incidents recorded in Victoria. This is used to calculate incident rate per 100 residents


Consumer Price Index
ABS
To adjust 2021 Census Rent data by adding the percentage growth in CPI of rent in Melbourne between 2021 and 2024


Estimated Resident Population
ABS
To adjust 2021 Census Population data to 2024


Metropolitan Melbourne regions and their local government areas
The State of Victoria Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP)
To visualize and compare data by regions








Table 1 summarizes data I collected for this analysis. There are three key data points I need for this analysis, namely rent price by suburb, crime rate by surburb and geospatial boundary of each suburb.
I collected rent price data from 2021 Census GeoPackages - Table G02, where Median weekly rent is provided (2021). While there are more recent sources of rental prices available, they are either less comprehensive, often missing data on outer areas, or locked behind paywall. 2021 Census is the most complete data source on rental price with true open access. However, since my analysis is anchored in 2024, yet the data is from 2021, I need to adjust rent data using the 2021 and 2024 consumer-price index (CPI) provided by Australia Bureau of Statitistics (2025a).
To calculate the crime rate, defined as incident rate per 100 residents, I needed data on crimes and population in Melbourne. I collected data on all criminal incidents in 2024 from Victoria’s Crime Statistics Agency (CSA). CSA collects recorded crime from Victoria Police to process and release to the public every quarter, thus, is the most up-to-date and official data source on Victoria crimes. Regarding population data, I collected it from 2021 Census GeoPackages - Table G01 (2021). Similar to rental data, this data is from 2021, thus, needed adjusting by annual population growth rate, which is calculated from Estimated Resident Population (ERP) provided by ABS (2025b).
The 2021 Census GeoPackages also offer geospatial data on suburb level, called Suburbs and Localities (SALs). I use this data to visualize two key variables on a map.
All data from ABS are licensed under Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International licence, and data from CSA are licensed under Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Australia license (2025c; n.d.)

title: Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?
text:
Calculation and assumptions

Price-to-Safety index
Price-to-Safety index is calculated as a weighted average of suburb-level weekly rent (60%) and incident rate (40%). This percentage indicates the relative importance of each factor to the overall index.
\[
\text{Price-to-Safety index} = 0.6 \times \text{Median weekly rent} + 0.4 \times \text{Incident rate}
\]

Estimate Median weekly rent for 2024
Median weekly rent in 2024 is calculated by multiple 2021 Census median weekly rent by Rent growth rate, which is defined as percentage change in CPI between 2021 and 2024.
\[
\text{Median weekly rent in 2024} = \text{Median weekly rent in 2021} \times (1 + \text{CPI in 2021}/\text{CPI in 2024})
\]
Assumptions: CPI is an estimate on State level, including both metropolitan and regional areas. I assume this is a good reflection of how rental price changes within Melbourne metropolitan areas.


Calculate Incident rate per 100 residents
\[
\text{Incident rate per 100 residents} = \frac{\text{incident counts}}{\text{population in 2024}} \times 100
\]


Estimate Population for 2024
Population in 2024 is calculated by multiplying 2021 Census population by Population growth rate between 2021 and 2024.
\[
\text{Population in 2024} = \text{Population in 2021} \times (1 + \text{ERP in 2024}/\text{ERP in 2021})
\]
Assumptions: While 2024 estimated population exists, they are not presented by suburb. Therefore, I need to calculate the population growth rate between 2021 and 2024 by assuming the reliability of this population estimate.


Harmonising suburbs and local government areas between Census data and CSA data
Assumption: There exists multiple suburbs that extend to more than one local government area (LGA) and metropolitan region, creating duplications when merging CSA data with Census data. This is because CSA data is presented by suburbs and LGAs, while Census data is presented by suburbs only. While this does not impact any calculation, it creates duplication during visualization.
Therefore, where duplications among extended suburbs happen, I keep the first entry and assume that the suburb only belongs to one LGAs or metropolitan region.



Suburb category based on Weekly rent and Incident rate
Looking into the relative impact of rent and incident rate, I decided to categorize suburbs into 4 quadrants:

Underrated: Rent is lower than the median rent of alls suburbs, and incident rate is lower than the median incident rate of all suburbs.
Overpriced: Rent is higher than the median rent of all suburbs, and incident rate is higher than the median incident rate of all suburbs.
Premium Safe: Rent is higher than the median rent of all suburbs, and incident rate is lower than the median incident rate of all suburbs.
Cheap Risk: Rent is lower than the median rent of all suburbs, and incident rate is higher than the median incident rate of all suburbs.

title: Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?
section: Systematic differences in rent and crime risk exists across regions: Melbourne CBD (Inner Metro Region) ranks lowest in both affordability and safety, while the East trumps.
text:
Systematic differences in rent and crime risk exists across regions: Melbourne CBD (Inner Metro Region) ranks lowest in both affordability and safety, while the East trumps.














Figure 1




No strong negative rent-safety link overall but clear regional clusters: inner/metro pay premium for location not safety.

The city (Inner Metro Region) is where the most incidents were recorded, while the rent here is second highest. As seen in Figure 1, most of its suburbs belong to the upper right quadrant where both rent and incident rates are higher than state median.
The more affluent areas (Inner South East and Eastern) have the highest Price-to-Safety index. Inner South East is home of the most affluent suburbs, i.e., Kooyong, Kew, Brighton, etc. Eastern is generally known for the higher middle class, reflecting in cheaper rents compared to Inner South East and Inner Metro Region, while maintaining superiorly low incident rates.

title: Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?
section: The best bet for Value suburbs (low rent, high safety) is in Eastern and Northern regions
text:
The best bet for Value suburbs (low rent, high safety) is in Eastern and Northern regions










Eastern and Southern have the highest percentage of suburbs categorized as “Value”. This is where renters are most likely to find the best deals.
The Western and Inner Metro region are not as preferred given the higher composition of “Not worth it” and “Overpriced” suburbs.

title: Are you paying higher rent for better security in Melbourne?
section: Explore the metrics on each suburb
text:
Explore the metrics on each suburb
The map and table below helps users look for metrics of specific suburbs. These visualization can assist the production of SEO articles, listing pages or landing pages where users can quickly assess one suburb over another.
